content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
Early Access Review
Short game time is due to the current lack of content, in the time I have spent with this game I've played all the tracks it has to offer, some more than once.Super Indie Karts is an indie racing game similar to the early Mario Karts game that is currently available through Steam Early Access. In Super Indie Karts you play as one of many indie characters and race against seven opponents on a variety of tracks, some of which come from the same games as the characters. Before I get underway I'd just like to point out that this game is still pretty early and is developed by one person so any negatives I mention about the game will have less of an impact on my Verdict than they would if this was a full release title, my review will be updated as the game is updated to reflect and changes made.+Charming pixel graphics+Well designed tracks and characters which fit the pixel art style excellently +Already has a lot of playable characters with more to be added by the time the game releases, many characters come from popular indie titles such as Fist of Awesome and Canabalt+The controls are great (I played using a 360 controller) and the karts feel very responsive+Quite a few different power-ups in the game which are all very good though I would definitely like to see a couple more+A couple of the power-ups have 'action cams' so you can see them do their work which is a fun mechanic+Good soundtrack which fits the game well+Brings back some good memories of the early Mario Kart games-Personally I found it a little bit too easy, even on the hardest of the three difficulties I was still coming first or second without putting much effort in-As mentioned there's not much content at the moment, only four of eight single player Grand Prix's are available to play and the other game modes aren't available yet-It takes about a second for the game to pause after you press the pause buttonWorth Noting:Super Indie Karts will be $5 cheaper upon releaseHere's a short video I recorded of the first Grand Prix event:


YouTube™ Video: El K. Goes for a Drive (Super Indie Karts Gameplay) 

			Views: 106		

			A quick look at Super Indie Karts' first Grand Prix Super Indie Karts is currently available through Steam Early Access on the Steam Store for £10.99: http://store.steampowered.com/app/323670/ Video...		

Verdict:Worth Purchasing (7.5/10)A great indie racing game with charming graphics, well designed tracks and great controls which is only let down by its lack of difficulty and content.This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposesEl K.

number of helpful: 19 of 26 people (73%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
Early Access Review
<Disclosure - This review was provided free for review purposes>Super Indie Karts is a back-to-basics kart racer boasting a unique indie roster and vibrant retro visuals. This is a review of the game in early access, so take it with a pinch of salt – all features may be subject to change and improvements – the final product will certainly be better than what is currently on offer. With that being said, let’s get to the review proper.Super Indie Karts should be pretty familiar to anyone who has ever played Mario Kart, Diddy King Racing, Sonic Drift etc. For the uninitiated however, in Super Indie Kart, you compete to come first place against seven other racers on wacky, themed courses filled with obstacles and power-ups. Those looking for a complex, robust driving game should bow out now – SIK doesn’t reinvent the wheel, but can capably hold its own with the kart racing series’ forerunners.Arguably the most important aspect of a racing game should be its controls, and thankfully, SIK controls smoothly for the most part. Taking corners can be quite tricky at first, and the drift function seems to be primarily used for the boost it grants rather than helping to actually make corners. It can take a bit of getting used to for fans of modern racers, but once familiarised with the controls, timing boosts and jumps while dodging obstacles at high speed becomes second nature and a lot of fun. Best played with a controller.The current roster boasts 26 characters, with a further 10 yet to be released making it a really meaty selection of potential racers. Unless you’re a devoted follower of the indie game scene, it’s likely that this will be your first time seeing a lot of these characters, and without knowing who they are and what game they come from, they can seem a little flat, with some characters looking particularly boring or out of place such as Elena or Cannabalt. However, for those in the know, seeing their favourite indie icons racing for victory is sure to be a treat. The overall character design is quite nice, and familiar or not, you’re sure to find a racer that suits you.The courses at present are a mixed bag. Most look well designed with a nice variety in layout and style. The best courses I found where the ones with broad turns and plenty of opportunities for drift boosts. At their worst, the tracks are riddled with sharp, 90 degree turns and littered with annoying, seemingly randomly placed obstacles – I believe the developer plans to tone down these obstacles somewhat, and this would be a welcome boon to the flow of the races.Graphically, the game features bright, vibrant tones and quirky retro sprites, very reminiscent of its SNES era progenitor. All the tracks are displayed in a classic mode 7 style which is rarely seen and old school Mario Kart or F-Zero fans are sure to appreciate. There is also a screen filter option to make the game look as though it is running on an old CRT monitor with screen curvature and scanlines. This is a very nice feature that retro gamers are sure to enjoy and thankfully, it isn’t too distracting to the point where you’ll be at a disadvantage. The retro fan service continues with the option to replace in-game button prompts with SNES, and Playstation button icons – Super Indie Karts is anything but shy when it comes to its origins. The soundtrack is equally charming, featuring a variety of upbeat chip tunes – nothing too standout, but pleasant nonetheless.At present the game is reasonably thin on content with only 15 available tracks, no multiplayer races and two newly added battle modes. These battle modes consist of the classic arena based combat mode where you attack by firing weapons, in addition to a Fist of Awesome inspired punch out mode where players swing for each other with giant boxing gloves mounted to their kart. While still very rough around the edges, these battle modes could prove promising and will likely be an enjoyable multiplayer experience. There are no unlockables yet meaning there is no incentive to racing beyond the race itself – If planning to buy this game anytime soon, be prepared for a brief experience.There’s not much more to say about Super Indie Karts, in the brief time I spent playing I had exhausted most of the available content and without multiplayer I would be unlikely to revisit it again for a good while, as content slowly builds up. Super Indie Karts is an enjoyable experience and a solid kart racer in its own right, and when finished, should be a very fun, expansive party game. However, at the moment, the only incentive to buying this game is to support the devs and get early impression/give feedback. The game's current price wil be the same upon release, so my advice is to hold off on a purchase unless you’re desperate for some retro kart racing action.Pros:+Great pixel graphics+Large roster of characters+Fun, classic kart racing.Cons:-Thin on content-Lack of multiplayerTentative Score: 7/10If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
Early Access Review
Before I say anything, I'd like to make it clear I did enjoy this game, I just wouldn't reccomend you to buy it.I loved zipping around the track, and I have a soft spot for any game that let's me play as Carol Tea of Freedom Planet, even if that does make me someone usually avoided at parties. Infact, the whole character set is actually pretty great, and aside from a few visuals, such as the melon-with-a-face (used in-game as a menu cursor among other things), which are awkwardly smooth for a retro-style video game, the graphics are absolutely great. It's deffinitely a fun game to look at. That's where the "but" comes in, and this is a big "but." It's a lot of fun to look at, but a lot less so to play. That's because this game cannot decide if it wants to be Mario Kart on the SNES or Mario Kart 8; the courses themselves are more like the SNES game, being flat and often very blocky, with only about half of the tracks having any real smooth turns. The turning controls themselves are also very comparible to SNES Mario Kart, being somewhat slidey and slow (though arguably a little too slow), but allowing for brisk and speedy turns using a slide. However, while these two design choices work well with each other, they're both made near-unenjoyable by the fact that rather than making the karts move only at a reasonable speed as in the SNES Mario Kart, allowing players to better judge turns and react to the other racers and track hazards without being hindered by the slower turning speeds, the game decides it needs to try to keep the player's attention by making every car go extremely fast. This leads to the problem that due to the slow turning and the quick speeds, by the time you notice an obsticle it's already too late to really avoid it. This, combined with the fact that the blocky track designs often require tight 45 degree turns, means you'll be hitting things a lot. This game has potential, but either they need to slow down the gameplay, or completely redesign the tracks.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								After almost 2h of playtime, I managed to beat all cups in 50cc (didn't play mirror yet). Here are my first impressions:+ It captures the feel and look of Super Mario Kart pretty well!+ Nice character and track variety+ you have multiple objectives in a race. Get first, collect the mushroom and collect a specific amount of money during the race. This is optional and raises the rank you earn at the end of the cup+ All the game modes you expect from Mario Kart are there, GP, Time Trial, Battle, Versus, ...+ the music is awesome!- the tracks are super colorful and full of hidden ways, items and other things. You feel really lost and need to learn every track before being able to get first everywhere- the developers really overdid it in terms of shortcuts. On some tracks, you can just use one shortcut after another until the end of the lap. Feels like every curve has 2 ways to drive it. Because of that you never know if you're driving the correct way. It's a bit too much- some soundeffects are really loud- drifting feels very unusual and needs some time to get it right. Doesn't feel as natural as Mario Kart at the beginningOverall I'm enjoying this game a lot. Most of my cons can be solved by the player by simply learning the tracks and the controls. Which is OK for a singleplayer game, but I feel like a Mario Kart-clone needs a better accessablity for new players.It doesn't really feel like an early access title to me, but it's strange that (at this moment) half of the tracks have no game references and are just colorful tracks. I also learned about many other promising indie titles with this game.I can definitely recommend this game!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I first saw Super Indie Karts, I thought it was kind of interesting since I like to play racing games. I was kind of disappointed when it didn't make its goal at first. When the Kickstarter re-emerged, I decided to back it and was happy when it made it. The game itself boasts Mode 7-style tracks, which I like since Super Mario Kart is one of my favorite classic games and I like Mode 7 being utilized in various ways. The racers consist of original characters and characters from various indie games such as Teslagrad, the Adventures of Pip, and Runbow.Currently, the game is in Beta and has several things missing (i.e. Time Trial, several cups, characters, etc.). Grand Prix  and Battle Mode are available for right now. Unfortunately, I only played Grand Prix since Battle Mode requires at least two players. Grand Prix consists of eight cups (five of them are playable) and three classes that have their own difficulty. Winning first place is the not the only objective here because you can collect Race Jewels and Golden Shrooms (which are similar to the Star item from Mario Kart series) to increase your overall rank for the cup.For the Grand Prix gameplay, you race against seven CPU racers in high-speed races and you can hinder them with items such as melons or homing coconuts. You can also perform drifts for difficult turns and speed boosts. I enjoy the gameplay since I love to go fast and avoiding danger on the track. However, you have to be on your toes when you want to achieve the highest rank. Be prepared for the races as you the CPU racers will give it their all to take first place from you. It can be fun and frustrating, especially in later classes. The graphics in the game is colorful and each character is sprited differently (some have a more 3d feel to them). There are 3d walls and 2d obstacles/hazards that can accommodate to the theme of each track as well. For Music/Sounds, I really enjoy the music of the game (especially Runbow Road), but the Golden Shroom theme playing at the same time as the current music is rather bothersome. Also, the voice grunting in the game is in most cases so-so. Doesn't really bother me, though. The controls are alright once you get the hang of it.In conclusion, if you love classic wacky racers such as Super Mario Kart and Diddy Kong Racing and enjoy some of the indie games, then give this game a whirl. There will be news tracks, characters, and more in the future.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pros:+Solid controls+A lot of love and care went into making the characters and stages authentic+Nice graphics+Minimal glitches+Nice music+An interesting spin on Mario Kart's gameplayCons:-No offense to the games' developers, but a lot of the characters featured are...not really notable. Canabalt, Duck Game, Guacamelee, Freedom Planet, Adventures of Pip, Shutshimi, Teslagrad, and Runbow are the only games featured that I've even heard of. I mean, I'm sure that the developer for this game approached some of the more recognizable developers and got turned down, but even so, the roster is a little underwhelming.-In fact, it kinda seems like some of the characters are just there to fill roster space. I don't know what Toto Temple Deluxe is, but for some reason it gets four separate characters that each have their own character slot.-That's another thing: there's a really noticeable unbalance in how much representation each game gets, especially in terms of characters. The Toto Temple Deluxe thing I mentioned earlier is the most flagrant example, but there are other games that, in my opinion, probably should only have one character representing them. But I guess it's kinda too late to change that.

								I was hesitant to buy an early access game after being told by so many people not too, as they are not finished and some developers do not finish, but for £6.99 with decent enough content to get my moneys worth already I went for it, and how many bugs can a Karting game have anyway?I am glad I went ahead and got the game, as love Mario Kart and wanted something similiar without bothering with emulating Mario Kart, as I always found Mario Kart very very easy (And I am by no means a good 'gamer', I am very casual).The find the challenge of the courses better then on Mario Kart, and love the soundtrack as well.Apparently online is coming in June or thereabouts.One thing I would like to see added is more weapons, as they are not as good or fun as in Mario Kart.But overall, loving how the game is, from the shoddy graphics to the soundtrack to the courses.Well worth £6.99.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								A fun little tittle that's not entirely like, but not un entirely like, Mario Kart. The TV filter is nifty and makes me wonder what other filters might be added later for other nostalgia attempts. It does what it comes to do, and I'd be lying if I said it wasn't fun. Looking forward to the new content coming and even the runbo track I hate made me laugh.Looking for another kart game that brings back the SNES style, enjoyed the other kart games like sonic's racing tittles? Well your next kart game has drifted into early access. Looking forward to playing this one online. Least I sure hope that online comes through. Everything else seems well under way, even the pitfalls of the game can be something to laugh at.Another thing to mention is that it doesn't seem to suffer from trying to push the same racers unrealistically to winning, meaning you can indeed play the game's point system realistically for the cup win without getting first place every time. At least so far. Something I believe well worth mentioning with rubberbanding mechanics past.When you hit your speedy stride here, you feel that rush, even just starting with the 50cc, you're already having fun.If I were to nit pick here, only a few of the characters I'm fond of so far, but there are still some there, and the sound ballancing feels like it needs a little work. That and though the control design as is, is more than functional, I want the ability to re map my controller. In this day and age, there's just no reason not to have the likes in the final product. Despite that, well worth the ten bucks, a steal if on sale, and a modern twist on a classic look with new track ideas that brings it's own flavor. This tittle is D bad friendly, yet analog ready.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								[EDIT: 03. 01.2017]Onscreenbuttons for the controller work, although the controller isn't automatically detected, but quite a few controller layouts are supported, for example PS4, SNES or OUYA layouts![ORIGINAL REVIEW]This isn't flatout bad, and I can see why people enoy this. But I have seen better.First of all, while my wired xbox-controller worked fine, the on-screen keycommands were still displayed for the keyboard.  And while it's not rocket science to figure three buttons out, it still holds back the "pick-up-and-play"-aspect I expect from a kart racer.The gameplay is very similar to the original Mario Kart. You drive, you throw things, you try to win. The controls, in my opinion, feel a bit floaty and lack the grip of similar kart racers, but maybe that's just me. What this game offers is challenge. The tracks are harder than you might expect, with a lot of sharp turns, many jumps, and an abundance of obstacles. And it doesn't help that, when you get hit, your driver AND the camera spins around, leaving you guessing whether you are still looking in the right direction.As for the tons of tracks and crossovers (SO MANY CHARACTERS!), it doesn't add much to the game. Every track and character feels pretty much the same. The idea behind the VR-TRAX, which are maybe 70 % of the tracks in the game, is that they look like tron-style meshes in different colours. I was underwhelmed.There are other aspects I don't like, for example the toned down music, the AI that seems as helpless as I am and so on, but I just wanted something quick, easy and fun to play with friends or alone. But apart from screaming "LOOK AT ALL THESE INDIE GAME CROSSOVERS" right in my ear, this doesn't offer much to me.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								Pretty decent kart racer designed to resembled Super Mario Kart art first glance, but actually houses more refined mechanics. Its current state as of this writing however is very work-in-progess as the stage count and character select are unfinished, and both time trials and online multiplayer are just currently absentWhat I feel will make or break this game for most are the indie games being highlighted here, which can be a very mixed bag. Absent are many "Indie Superstars", leaving Juan from Guacamelee as the highest profile name present, with some other notable characters like Carol Tea from Freedom Planet as a runner-up name the average consumer might have a chance of recognizing. I must stress the roster still isnt done, so there is a chance for "Big Indie" names like Shovel Knight, Skullgirls, or Shantae to possibly grace the game but I wouldn't recommend buying the game banking on the unknown.Its in a decent enough state for some good local fun, but hold off for now if you want to play online.

								Game isn't 'bad', but it isn't great either! Fist of Awesome? ewww. Wasted oppertunity for a SMK style game with indie characters, in Mario Kart the characters are iconic, we've had alot of fantastic and iconic indie games over the years and practically none are in this game sadlyAlso, while it is somewhat a good SMK clone, its gameplay is somewhat flawed, someone else points it out alot better in their review but the karts go much faster then they do in SMK dispite the game having similair track designsAnother reason I'm giving this a thumbs down is due to the developer ignoring customer feedbackHere he is saying he'd consider putting a cheat in, re-adding the original look, but it would add a whopping 50mb to the game, yes a whopping 50mbhttp://steamcommunity.com/app/323670/discussions/0/359543951706265641/Now here he is, months later.. Saying it'll never be possible, due to this game being on the Ouya.. That means he has to have a strict limitation on file size http://steamcommunity.com/app/323670/discussions/0/135507403157130368/I suggested he could add it as a cheat for PC only, and ignore the limitations of the ouya holding the game back, but I never got a replyI simply can't recommend a game that won't get new content added 'based on the fact it's on some weird console', his priorities for this game are very strangeI DONT UNDERSTAND WHY 50MB HAS TO BE SUCH A BIG DEAL

number of helpful: 8 of 21 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								For a game that's trying to be like Super Mario Kart mixed with Konami Racers, it sure fails hard at it. Let me count the ways!The AI is faster then it should be on some tracks while also slower on others.You slide like your on ice with every small turn, more so then Super Mario Kart.Drifting slows you down, forcing you to snake with level 1 boost.Everything bounces you everywhere.Weapons and hazards are too powerful, slowing or dead stopping you longer then you should be.No invulnerability frames after being hit meaning damage stacks.Heatseekers used in first place hunt down second place.Using controller causes shots to be fire backwards more then forward.Every track feels small and cramped.The first cup is way harder then any of the other cups.Duck Stage is a mess, even the AI can't complete it.Runbow Stage is broken as it places you super close to the color you need to stay way when you fall, forcing you to fall in the holes again.The only recognizable characters (IMO) are Carol Tea, Juan, and Duck but even then; You cannot identify anyone from behind them.I do not recommend getting this "game" even if your a fan of any of the characters found in this "game". Go buy Sonic & All-Stars Racing Transformed if your looking for a good "Kart-Racer" on PC.
